title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
WarningResearch in Progress



This document represents an active research pipeline. Algorithms and preliminary findings are subject to change as more data is integrated.

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
2.1 The Source of the Formula
The Brihat Samhita dedicates multiple chapters (Adhyayas) to natural phenomena. Specifically, Chapter 32 (Bhukampa-lakshana-adhyaya) describes signs of impending earthquakes.

2.1.1 Key Astrological Rules

Planetary Conjunctions (Yuti): The proximity of malefic planets in specific â€œsensitiveâ€ signs is a primary trigger.

Mars-Ketu Conjunction: Mars represents fire and raw energy; Ketu (South Node) represents sudden, explosive release. Their union is often cited as a precursor to violent volcanic or seismic activity.
Saturn-Mars Aspects: The conflict between Shani (compression/pressure) and Mangal (expansive heat) creates tectonic tension.

Eclipses (Grahana): Solar and lunar eclipses within 15 days of each other create high gravitational tidal stress, which may act as a trigger for fault lines already under pressure.
Zodiacal Ingress (Sankranti): The entry of major planets (Saturn, Jupiter) into fixed signs (Sthira Rashis) or earth signs (Prithvi Rashis) is tested for correlation with increased seismic activity.

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
2.2 The Koorma Chakra
A central concept in our future roadmap is the Koorma Chakra (The Tortoise Chart), which maps the zodiac onto the geography of the Earth. This allows for the personalization of seismic predictions to specific regions (e.g., Aries ruling certain mountainous terrains).

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
3.1 The Detection Pipeline
The following diagram illustrates how we process raw astronomical data into correlation reports:
graph TD
    A[USGS Seismic Data] --> B[Filter Magnitude >= 7.0]
    C[Swiss Ephemeris] --> D[Daily Planetary Positions]
    B & D --> E[Correlation Engine]
    E --> F{Combination Found?}
    F -- Yes --> G[Statistical Validation Chi-Square]
    F -- No --> H[Background Noise Analysis]
    G --> I[WIP Report Generation]

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
3.2 Core Algorithmic Logic
The primary function in our codebase, identify_planetary_conjunction, uses the following mathematical logic:

Normalization: Longitude \(\lambda\) is normalized to \(0-360^\circ\).
Angular Distance: The separation \(\theta\) between two planets \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) is: \[\theta = \min(|\lambda_{P_1} - \lambda_{P_2}|, 360 - |\lambda_{P_1} - \lambda_{P_2}|)\]
Tolerance Check: A conjunction is flagged if \(\theta \le \delta\), where \(\delta\) is usually \(8.0^\circ\) (the classical Deeptansha orb).


3.2.1 Python Implementation Detail


Code
# Simplified logic from use_cases/earthquake/scripts/earthquake_planetary_analysis.py

def detect_conjunction(pos1, pos2, tolerance=8.0):
    diff = abs(pos1 - pos2)
    if diff > 180:
        diff = 360 - diff
    return diff <= tolerance

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
4.1 Successes: Principle Validation
The following table highlights major historical earthquakes where our algorithms correctly identified the corresponding astrological signatures (Yogas).

These â€œHitsâ€ affirm that when the specific conditions of Mass Density (multiple planets) or Gravitational Peak (Eclipses) are met, the probability of a high-magnitude event increases significantly.

title: Seismic Sensitivity: A Computational Approach to Medini Jyotish
text:
4.2 Nuanced Analysis: The â€œMissesâ€
It is equally important to report where the formula was silent. In our dataset of top 20 earthquakes (Mag 8.0+) from 1950-2020: * 12 out of 20 events matched at least one major Medini rule. * 8 out of 20 events occurred during relatively â€œquietâ€ astrological periods.
Example of a Miss: * 1964 Alaska Earthquake (Mag 9.2): While the second largest quake ever recorded, our standard â€œMars-Ketuâ€ or â€œSaturn-Marsâ€ algorithms did not flag this date as critical.

4.2.1 Investigating the Divergence
The existence of â€œMissesâ€ suggests two possibilities: 1. Incomplete Rule Set: We may need to incorporate more subtle factors like Koorma Chakra (regional sensitivity) or Sanghatta Rashi (Vedha/Obstruction points). 2. Different Mechanisms: Some earthquakes may be purely tectonic â€œslipsâ€ with no cosmic trigger, whereas others are â€œcosmically induced.â€
